What is the Pomodoro technique?

The Pomodoro technique involves using a timer to divide work into focused blocks of time (usually 25 minutes) separated by a short break, usually five minutes.

After four consecutive blocks of working time, a longer break is taken, about 20 or 30 minutes.

Each 25-minute work block is called a "pomodoro." If you feel the need to do something different from work during a period of concentration, note it. Over time, you\'ll train yourself to be more productive during each pomodoro.

The benefits of the Pomodoro technique come from frequent breaks, which help keep your mind fresh. Focused time locks also force you to meet fixed limits, so it will encourage you to complete a task more quickly or, in the case of a large task, extend it over several pomodoros.

This Pomodoro method is useful in cases of teleworking.

Work duration and rest times may vary depending on what you prefer, but here\'s the basic process:

  1. Start a 25-minute timer
  2. Work until the timer sounds
  3. Take a short five-minute break
  4. Every four pomodoros (focus periods), take a longer break, usually 20 to 30 minutes

Because the whole technique is focused on timing your focus periods and breaks, it\'s helpful to rely on a timer app.

Who invented it?

At the university, the final exam season causes a two-week session. Many students study all night and increase dangerous levels of caffeine. But after a while, studying more doesn\'t really help. You\'re reading the same material, but your brain is so exhausted that you won\'t hold anything back.

That\'s what Francesco Cirillo discovered during his first year of college. After realizing that he was getting distracted and wasn\'t using his study time efficiently, he grabbed a tomato-shaped kitchen timer, adjusted it for 10 minutes, and tried to work solidly during those 10 minutes without doing anything else.

And it worked: forcing himself to concentrate before rewarding himself with a break helped him do more, even with rest time. That is why the Pomodoro technique is used to study oppositions.

Where does its name come from?

With further testing and adjustments, Cirillo settled on a structured framework for what he called the Pomodoro Technique. This name comes from the Italian word pomodoro,meaning "tomato", in reference to the original kitchen timer used for its creation, which was a tomato.

What is this technique used for?

The Pomodoro technique is mainly used to increase productivity at work.

Proponents of the Pomodoro Technique compile long lists of the benefits it provides. Here are five benefits to boosting your work.

1. Manage distractions and control your time

The Pomodoro technique allows you to take control of your own time. If a co-worker approaches you in the middle of a pomodoro, use the "report → negotiate → schedule → call back" approach to postpone the interruption until you\'re ready. Kindly inform that you are busy, but negotiate and schedule a schedule when you will be available to help. Then, when you\'re ready, invite them to come back and talk to you.

When the distractions are internal (email, cat memes, or you suddenly remember it\'s your mother\'s birthday), write them down on paper and get to the end of your pomodoro. During a break, you can send your friend a new cat meme or order flowers for your mother.

2. Increase responsibility

At the end of each pomodoro, take a minute to write down everything you\'ve accomplished. Keeping track of your work will allow you to deliver an impressive and transparent productivity report to your boss.

3. Improve weekly and quarterly planning

In addition to increasing accountability, recording your achievements will make it easier to plan effectively in the future. Over time, you\'ll be able to accurately estimate how many pomodoros you\'ll need to complete a certain type of project.

For example, a writer may notice that, on average, it takes him three pomodoros to research a new article, one pomodoro to outline his thoughts, and two pomodoros to write the article. Later, when they set goals for the amount of content they will produce in a week, they will have a better idea of how many articles they can write based on how much time they have available.

4. Decrease back pain and mental fatigue

The Pomodoro technique requires users to take regular breaks. You can walk around the office, have a snack, or fill your water bottle.

Getting up to stretch your legs prevents the onset of desk-induced back and shoulder pain. Similarly, allowing your mind to wander for a few minutes reduces the exhaustion of the workday, and when you feel good physically and mentally, you do more things.

5. Stay motivated

As you approach the end of a pomodoro and your work is almost finished, it becomes an exciting race against time to finish before time runs out.

Emotion motivates you to work faster, even when you would normally start slowing down. These short bursts of motivation add up over time and will increase the amount of work you do.

How is it applied?

Here I explain the 5-step process to implement the Pomodoro technique:

  1. Choose your task and the total time to work on it.
  2. Set a timer to 25 minutes (either with an egg timer or with an app).
  3. Work on the task for 25 minutes. Avoid all distractions and impulses to multitask.
  4. Take a 5-minute break to renew your energy and start another Pomodoro.
  5. Take a break of 15-30 minutes after completing four Pomodoros.

Simple, but very effective. When you use this technique, you will see a significant improvement in your productivity and ability to get things done.

Guidelines for Maximizing Results

There are four guidelines that can maximize your results:

  • Breaks are not optional:When the doorbell rings, stop working,get up and take a break. You need this time for your mind to relax and energize for the next task. Use it for: doing simple exercises, having a snack, going to the bathroom, stretching, or making a cup of tea. It doesn\'t really matter what you do, as long as you\'re taking a break.
  • Time Duration = Task Challenge:The actual amount of time you spend fully focused on a task depends on its level of difficulty. Easy tasks (i.e. a low level of concentration) can be completed in blocks of time of 50 minutes (2 Pomodoros) or 1 hour and 15 minutes (3 Pomodoros). The most difficult tasks can be completed using the standard 25-minute time block. Really, the amount of Pomodoros you do should relate to how long you can focus on a task without feeling distracted.
  • Partial pomodoros Do Conde: If you do 10 minutes of work it is still work. If you get interrupted, all you have to do is record your time and then add it to the next Pomodoro. Once you\'ve completed that Pomodoro, you\'ll get credit for making two Pomodoros. You can do quality work in small blocks of time (such as 5 to 10 minutes).
  • Batch-related pomodoros:Tasks that take less than 25 minutes should be grouped together rather than done separately. For example, I have a task called "social media communication," which includes talking to people via email, Twitter, Pinterest, Google+, and Facebook. Each site can take only five minutes of my time, so I\'ve developed a system where I run a few consecutive Pomodoros and review them all at once.

Advantages for productivity in teleworking

The Pomodoro technique can have important advantages in case of using teleworking.

How often do you tap your cell phone screen and get distracted? According to one study, users touch their phones 2,617 times a day. In addition, we spend about 3 hours a day with our phones.

There is a constant flow of information, social media notifications, and emails that take up our time. The result is that our productivity is getting lower and lower.

The problem isn\'t just the distraction, but the time and energy it takes to regain your focus on your work or study. Regaining full concentration takes about 20 minutes, and after giving in to the need to look at Facebook, another 20 minutes pass.

How can we teach our brain to resist all these self-disruptions and train it to fully focus on one task? This is where the Pomodoro Technique comes in!

You will increase productivity with this technique by performing remote work with these simple steps:

  • Make a list of tasks to perform
  • Reduce distractions:close your email, your social networks and put your mobile phone in silence.
  • Start your first Pomodoro session
  • Take advantage of your 5-minute break
  • Repeat the session
  • Take a longer break
  • Mark the completed task in your list.
